Description: Egyptian terracotta life-size male figure fragment in Cypriot style. Fragment of nose with moustash of large, almost life size male figure. Small traces of white wash or coating covered with red paint. Cyproit style in Egyptian Nile silt, probably Nile Delta silt fabric. Red-brown fabric with grey core and brown surface. Abundant fine gold mica and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Large life-size ceramic sculptures made in Cyprus have similar circular applied pellets for beard and moustache hair such as this example during the early 6th century BC (Karageorghis1993, nos 220, 221). This is made from a local Nile silt fabric, suggesting Cypriot style figures were copied and made in Naukratis. A late 7th to mid 6th century BC date is most likely. Karageorghis, V. 1993. The coroplastic art of ancient Cyprus. III. The Cypro-Archaic period. Large and medium size sculpture. Nicosia, University of Cyprus.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.001) (Phase 1)
